bibl.title: Bartholomeo Massulo v. Henry M. White. Assignment of Error
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the Court of the United STates for the District of Washington
Filed in the United States District Court
Service of within assignment of error and receipt of copy admitted this 11th day of April 1919
In the Matter of the Application of BARTHOLOMEO MASSULO, for a writ of habeas corpus.

Now comes the complainant in the above entitled cause and files the following assignment of error upon which he will rely upon his prosecution of the appeal in the above entitled cause from the order made by this Honorable Court on the 3rd day of March, 1919.

That the order and warrant of deportation made and entered by the Secretary of Labor of the United States or by the General Commissioner of Immigration under his direction and affirmed by the District Court on the 3rd day of March, 1919, is void for want of jurisdiction on the part of the said Secretary of Labor or General Commissioner of Immigration to enter such order.

That there is no evidence to sustain the findings of said Commissioner or Secretary; that the complainant was at the time of his entry into the United States a person likely to become a public charge.

That there is no evidence to sustain the finding of said Commissioner or Secretary that the complainant was at the time of his entry or since that time, found advocating and teaching anarchy and the overthrow, by force or violence, of the Government of the United States and of all forms of law and the assasination of public officials.
That the court erred in denying the application of the complainant for a writ of habeas corpus and in sustaining the order of deportation made by said Secretary of Labor.

That said Commissioner and Secretary in entering the order of deportation herein and the said Court in sustaining said order deprived the complainant of his liberty without due process of law and denied him his rights under the provisions of the Fifth Article of the Amendment of the Constitution of the United States.
WHEREFORE, the appellant prays that said order be reversed, annulled and held for naught, and for such other relief as may be proper in the premises.
